Analysis: The correct answer is: D. Subcoical leukoencephalopathy. Binswanger's disease (also known as subcortical vascular dementia, leukoencephalopathy, or chronic white matter disease) is a type of dementia that occurs in middle age or older adults due to damage to the white matter of the brain. It usually develops slowly and progresses over many years. The condition results from damage to small blood vessels in the brain. This leads to reduced oxygen and nutrient supply to the brain and death of nerve cells.

Harrison, Medicine, 18th/Ch.279)Fluorine in Drinking WaterFluorine exists naturally in water and in varying amounts in foods and air.Fluoride concentration in drinking water varies from about 0.02 to 10 mg/L. In many areas of the world, concentrations of fluoride exceed 0.5 mg/L and have been associated with dental fluorosis.Fluridosis is a disease characterized by discoloration of the teeth and skeletal changes. The symptoms are usually mild and include chalky white or brown spots on the enamel of the permanent teeth. These spots may be seen at any age but are most often observed between 5 and 10 years of age.The skeletal changes are usually confined to the jaws and the spine and are more severe in children than in adults.Severe cases may produce crippling deformities in the jaw and spinal column.Crippling fluorosis is caused by a concentration of 10 mg/L or more.

The correct answer is: A. CD 1. Ans. a (CD 1). (Ref. Robbins 8th/pg. 225; Basic Pathology 7th/pg. 106; Basic pathology 8th/pg. 102)T cells are derived from stem cells in the bone marrow. They have an antigen receptor that is encoded by two different genes, one on each chromosome. The genes are arranged such that if they are paired, they code for identical receptors. This is referred to as allelic exclusion. Each T cell has a receptor that recognizes only a single antigenic determinant. In other words, all the T cells of a given individual recognize only a limited number of antigens because they recognize only a limited number of antigens, and thus the T cell repertoire is quite limited.

Kallmann syndromeKallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder in which males are infertile because they have absent or low levels of testosterone and are unable to produce sperm. The syndrome is caused by mutations in genes that code for proteins that form structures in the nose that detect odor molecules.

CO2Pneumoperitoneum is a technique of insufflation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into the peritoneal cavity to create a pneumoperitoneum which is required in laparoscopic procedures. The use of CO2 has become the standard practice, since it does not dissolve in blood and is readily absorbed by the body, and therefore, causes no systemic side effects.Pleural insufflation can also be performed with CO2.

The correct answer is: A. Succinylcholine. Ans. A: Succinylcholine Succinylcholine is an anaesthetic muscle relaxant used for induction of anaesthesia. It is an irreversible skeletal muscle relaxant that causes profound paralysis of muscles, and may cause fatal respiratory arrest. Succinylcholine has no effect on the neuromuscular junction in patients with myasthenia gravis. Thus, succinylcholine can be safely used in patients with myasthenia gravis during anesthesia.

The correct answer is: D. All of these. Ans. d. All of these (Ref: KDT 7/e p32)Atropine is a competitive antagonist of nicotinic receptors and muscarinic receptors. Atropine blocks the action of acetylcholine by competitively binding to its receptor sites. This leads to blockade of nicotinic receptors, which are responsible for increased skeletal muscle strength. It also blocks the effect of acetylcholine in the autonomic nervous system, leading to blockade of both M1 and M2 receptors causing bradycardia and increased blood pressure.

The correct answer is: C. Will be removed by multinucleated giant cells. Apexification: The technique of replacing calcium hydroxide with a biocompatible, non-calcifying material. It is used for the treatment of immature teeth with vital pulps. The procedure involves the placement of a small amount of calcium hydroxide into the root canal system. This induces an inflammatory response that results in the formation of a fibrous apexification barrier within the canal. This barrier isolates the immature pulp from the external environment and allows it to mature and form a vital tooth.

The correct answer is: A) Bleeding. Ans. is 'a' i.e., Bleeding Meckels diveiculum o Meckel's diveiculum is a common congenital anomaly, arising from the distal pa of the ileum.o It arises from the umblical end of the ileum and is situated in the lesser poion of the jejunum (not in the ileum).o The duodenal wall is usually intact, but there may be a thin walled diverticulum at the junction of the ileum and jejunum.o The most common site for this anomaly is the junction of the ileum with the proximal jejunum, but it can occur anywhere along the alimentary tract.o Meckel's diveiculum is lined by the mucosa of the jejunum, which may have an increased number of lymphatic follicles, a feature not seen in the ileum.o Meckel's diveiculum occurs in 1-2% of population.o Most of the patients are asymptomatic and develop symptoms later in life.o The most common symptom is intestinal obstruction due to intussusception or adhesions, which develops in 30% of cases.o About 25% of patients present with acute abdomen due to diverticulitis, bleeding, perforation or intussusception.o Diverticulitis is the most serious complication of Meckel's diveiculum, occurring in about 5-10% of cases.o Diverticulitis may lead to perforation, peritonitis, fistula formation and abscess formation.o Intestinal obstruction is the second most common cause of presentation in Meckel's diveiculum.About 10% of patients present with gastrointestinal bleeding and about 4% develop diverticulitis.

The correct answer is: D. bulbar palsy. Diffuse esophagus spasm: Esophageal spasms are a group of esophageal motility disorders that affect the smooth muscle layer of the esophagus. They may be divided into two types: diffuse esophageal spasms (DES) and focal esophageal spasms. Achalasia cardia: Achalasia, also known as cardiospasm or esophageal dyskinesia, is a disease in which there is a loss of normal peristalsis in the esophagus. The esophagus loses its ability to squeeze food down into the stomach. This leads to difficulties with swallowing solids and liquids. Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal cancer is a disease in which malignant cells form in the tissues of the esophagus. Esophageal cancer is the eighth most common cause of cancer deaths worldwide. It is more common in men than women. The most common type of esophageal cancer is adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. This occurs in the lower esophagus where it comes in contact with the stomach. Bulbar palsy: Bulbar palsy is a neurological condition characterized by weakness and lack of coordination in the muscles of the face, tongue and throat, and sometimes the arms and legs. The bulbar region refers to the brainstem area that controls movement of the muscles of the face, tongue and throat.

The correct answer is: D. Both a lesion subjacent to the pleura in the lower pa of an upper lobe and active disease in the mediastinal lymph nodes. Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) may present as a single or multiple lesions in any part of the lungs, but typically they are located in the lower pa of an upper lobe or the middle zone of a lower lobe. The presence of active TB can be demonstrated by finding tubercle bacilli in sputum or by radiographic evidence of an infiltrate or cavity in the lung. Lesions that are subjacent to the pleura are not indicative of active pulmonary TB.

Pheochromocytomas may be found anywhere along the sympathetic nervous system or in the adrenal medulla. Most pheochromocytomas are sporadic; however, they are sometimes associated with genetic conditions such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, and Carney complex.

The correct answer is: A. Presence of inflammation. Apoptosis: It is a form of cell death that involves an orderly series of events leading to the programmed elimination of cells. Apoptosis is a normal biological process, which occurs in many tissues and organs during development. Apoptosis is also involved in the regulation of immune response by eliminating self-reactive lymphocytes. In the skin, apoptosis is involved in the removal of keratinocytes from the epidermis and in the renewal of epithelial tissue. The process is regulated by pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins. Apoptosis is different from necrosis, another form of cell death, in that the former does not involve inflammatory response.

The correct answer is: B. I band of the sarcomere. Option 1: A band of the sarcomere- A band is the region between the Z lines, where only thick filaments are present. The A band does not change in length when the muscle fibers contract. Option 2: I band of the sarcomere- The I band is the region between the M line and the Z line, where only thin filaments are present. The I band gets shorter when the muscle fibers contract. Option 3: Thick filaments- The thick filaments do not change in length when the muscle fibers contract. Option 4: Thin filaments- Thin filaments are attached to the actin cross-bridges that attach to the thick filaments. These actin cross-bridges get shorter when the muscle fibers contract.

The correct answer is: C. bce. Pituitary gland:- The pituitary gland, also known as the hypophysis or "master gland", is an endocrine gland that sits at the base of the brain, above the nasal cavity, connected to the hypothalamus by a stalk called the infundibulum. It is a conical structure about the size of a pea. It is divided into two parts: the anterior lobe (adenohypophysis) and the posterior lobe (neurohypophysis). The anterior lobe produces hormones that control other endocrine glands, while the posterior lobe stores and releases hormones produced elsewhere. The pituitary gland receives blood supply through two sources: the anterior pituitary is supplied by branches of the anterior cerebral aery, while the posterior pituitary is supplied by a branch of the hypothalamic aery (the nerve supply comes from the hypothalamus). The pituitary gland can be separated from the optic chiasm by the diaphragma sellae, but the optic chiasm is usually below the pituitary gland. The sphenoid sinus may extend down over the pituitary gland, although this does not happen in all people. Ref: Robbins 9th edition Pgno:510

This amount of water should be added to 2 litres of boiled water.

Thrice per weekHemodialysis is a method of removing waste products from the blood by using an external filter, called a dialyzer or artificial kidney, to remove wastes and excess fluid from the body. Hemodialysis may be performed several times each week. The most common schedule is three sessions each week. Each session lasts about 4 hours. In some cases, patients receive hemodialysis four or five times each week. Hemodialysis is usually performed at home, but it can also be done at a hospital or clinic.

The correct answer is: A. Superior thyroid artery. The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a cranial nerve that emerges from the vagus nerve just above the carina of the trachea. A: B lymphocytes Tuberculin skin test (TST): The tuberculin skin test (TST) measures the immune response in the skin of a person who has been exposed to tuberculosis. A small amount of tuberculin (purified protein derivative) is injected under the skin on the inside of the forearm. After 12 to 18 hours, the site is examined for a reaction. The reaction appears as a raised area of redness and swelling that may be larger than 5 cm in diameter. This reaction is called a "tuberculin induration" or "tuberculin skin test positive".

The correct answer is: B. Staphylococcus aureus. Microorganisms producing a distinct blue pigment are usually Staphylococcus aureus, whereas ADP-ribosylation toxins are usually produced by Clostridium perfringens. Staphylococcus aureus produces golden yellow to brownish yellow pigment. Staphylococcus epidermidis produces greenish white pigments. Staphylococcus aureus produces leukocidin which causes destruction of leukocytes and neutrophils. It also produces exfoliative toxin X, which is responsible for the exfoliative erythema of the skin. Staphylococcus aureus is also capable of producing enterotoxins which are responsible for food poisoning. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram negative bacterium, so it does not produce blue pigment. Pseudomonas aeruginosa can produce green pigment but not blue. Enterococcus faecalis produces greenish yellow pigment.

Harrison's medicine 16th/1047)TREATMENT OF CHLOROQUINE RESISTANT MALARIA# The treatment of choice for chloroquine resistant malaria is mefloquine, artemisinin combination therapy or atovaquone-proguanil.# Artemisinin combination therapy (ACT) is recommended by WHO for the treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria in all age groups in all settings.# ACT consists of artemisinin derivatives (artemether or artesunate) combined with another antimalarial drug.# Artemisinin derivatives are more potent than any other anti-malarial drugs and are active against all the species of Plasmodium except P. vivax and P. ovale.# ACT has been shown to have an advantage over monotherapy by reducing parasite counts and reducing the relapse rate.

The correct answer is: D. Zaleplon. Drugs that facilitate GABA action are: Zolpidem, zaleplon, zopiclone, eszopiclone These drugs act by facilitating the GABA action without producing sedation, hence these are non-sedating hypnotics. They are used in insomnia. They also have no anticonvulsant or muscle relaxing actions, therefore they are not used in seizure disorders or for muscle relaxation. They do not alter sleep architecture.

The correct answer is: D. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.. Ewing's Sarcoma is a small round cell tumor (SRCT). It usually occurs in adolescents, but may occur at any age. The classic location is the diaphysis of the long bones of the body, especially the femur, tibia, humerus, and radius. In children, the classic location is the shaft of the femur. The classic presentation is an acute onset of pain and swelling in the affected limb. The pain can be severe and may mimic that of an acute osteomyelitis. There may also be fever, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy. The typical radiographic finding is an expansile, non-uniform mass with a "moth-eaten" appearance. Histologically, the cells are small, round, and have fine, delicate, eosinophilic cytoplasm. They form nests or sheets. There may be a central "nuclear zone" containing large nuclei, which may have a bizarre appearance. A translocation between chromosomes 11 and 22 is seen in most cases. This is called the EWS-FLI1 fusion gene. The diagnosis is confirmed by immunohistochemistry for S100 protein, which is expressed in most cases.

The correct answer is: D. Desferrioxamine is treatment of choice. Ans. d. Desferrioxamine is treatment of choiceHemochromatosis is a genetic disorder in which iron accumulates in the body. In hemochromatosis, excess iron builds up in the liver, joints, pancreas, heart, and other organs, causing tissue damage and organ failure.If left untreated, iron overload can lead to serious complications such as cirrhosis, diabetes, arthritis, impotence, heart attack, or even death. The only effective way to treat hemochromatosis is regular phlebotomy (blood removal) to remove the excess iron.

OsteoradionecrosisOsteoradionecrosis (ORN) or radiation osteonecrosis is a complication of radiotherapy that occurs in tissues that have been irradiated, usually following head and neck cancer treatment. The most common sites are the jaw bones, but other bones can be affected. It is characterized by necrosis of bone tissue, often resulting in infection and eventual death of the bone.

The correct answer is: C. It does not cause alopecia. Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that inhibits microtubule formation. It is used in treatment of acute lymphocytic leukemia, neuroblastoma, and Hodgkin's disease. Side effects include peripheral neuropathy, alopecia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, hypokalemia, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, neutropenia, myelosuppression, pulmonary toxicity, and neurotoxicity.

The correct answer is: A. Microcytic hypochromic. Ans. A. Microcytic hypochromicMegaloblastic anemia (megaloblastic macrocytic anemia) is a group of anemias that are characterized by the presence of megaloblasts in the bone marrow, which leads to ineffective erythropoiesis and megaloblastic anemia (macrocytic anemia).Megaloblastic anemias are usually caused by deficiencies of vitamin B12 or folic acid. These vitamins play an essential role in DNA synthesis and red blood cell maturation, and they are needed for proper function of the methionine synthase enzyme. Deficiencies can be due to dietary deficiency, malabsorption, and reduced synthesis.Megaloblastic anemias may also be caused by drugs and alcohol abuse, some types of cancer, and genetic disorders, including Fanconi anemia and Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.Megaloblastic anemia results from impaired maturation of red blood cells. In the absence of effective erythropoiesis, the reticuloendothelial system breaks down and releases iron. This release of iron leads to hyperferritinemia and decreased iron stores (iron deficiency).

It may also be used to treat other conditions related to low levels of acetylcholine, such as agitation in people with Alzheimer's disease, dementia associated with Parkinson's disease, or dementia associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration. Ans. is 'b' i.e., Henoch-Schonlein purpura o The clinical features of Henoch-Schonlein purpura are:-1) Skin - Purpura - most common skin manifestation - seen over buttocks, thighs, shins, and ankles, but not on palms and soles.2) Abdominal pain and ahropathy - abdominal pain may be severe and associated with bloody diarrhoea and vomiting.3) Arthropathy - arthritis (most common) and arthralgia.4) Renal involvement - 50% cases may have renal involvement which presents as proteinuria or hematuria.

The correct answer is: D. Retinal detachment. Ans. D. Retinal detachmentRetinal detachment is a condition in which the retina detaches from its underlying layer of supportive tissue (the pigment epithelium). The retina is a light-sensitive membrane that lines the back of the eye. Retinal detachment can occur when fluid leaks under the retina, or when scar tissue pulls on the retina. It can also result from other conditions such as severe nearsightedness, retinal holes or tears, inflammation, or trauma. Retinal detachment can cause loss of vision if not treated promptly.

The correct answer is: C. |Peripheral resistence | cardiac output. Ans. is 'c' i.e., | Peripheral resistance | cardiac output "Neurogenic shock occurs due to loss of sympathetic stimulation of the vascular system." -KDT-7th/1049o In neurogenic shock, there is a marked reduction in cardiac output (CO) which results from reduced preload, contractility and afterload.o The drop in CO in neurogenic shock is mainly due to decreased preload rather than decreased contractility.o The fall in CO causes a marked increase in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) and venous pooling which leads to hypotension.o Therefore, in neurogenic shock, there is a fall in both SVR and CO.
